title: Tax cuts will push vital public services to the brink | Letters
content: Frances Ryan is right to highlight the increasing consensus between Labour and the Tories on cutting taxation, including its negative consequences for much-needed investment in public services and the reduction of destitution, poverty and inequality (I believe taxation is a great public good, but I look at my tax return and ask: what are we paying for?, 11 January). Adopting this government‚Äôs approach to fiscal responsibility, as Labour seem set on, will only widen inequalities and its damaging consequences for children‚Äôs health, education and wellbeing, as comprehensively evidenced by Sir Michael Marmot‚Äôs 2020 review. And what is so blinkered is Labour‚Äôs failure to engage the public with the short- and longer-term personal and economic costs of maintaining the status quo on taxation. Even a modest approach to progressive taxation would provide the funding to shift Labour‚Äôs policy agenda from piecemeal tinkering to reform, from rationing to needs-led public services ‚Äì offering a progressive vision to win the hearts and minds of the electorate. Prof Mike Stein University of York  ‚Ä¢ I share Frances Ryan‚Äôs indignation at the government and the opposition‚Äôs refusal to raise more taxes from the wealthy and affluent in order to rebuild our public services and reduce poverty. I can‚Äôt for the life of me see why such callousness should be a vote-winner. However, it also baffles me that no one seems to question the recent hikes in UK military spending, which, between 2020 and 2025, will be the largest sustained increase for 30 years: spending which fuels the devastation of lives and of our already fragile and polluted planet. What our country needs is a government of national unity, to create a radical rescue plan for the UK and beyond: one in which those who have the most will contribute the most, for the benefit of us all. Diana Francis Bath ‚Ä¢ So, ending non-dom tax status will fund 700,000 dental appointments and help correct the tragic state of dentistry in the UK (Britain has suffered terribly under these Tories, especially our children. The only word for it is neglect, 10 January). It will also enable free breakfast clubs in primary schools and address the worsening ill health of children. Do the figures stack up? Well, I hope so. But what of our decrepit public services, our diminished NHS, lack of care for elderly people, etc? Frances Ryan in her piece correctly challenges the failure of Keir Starmer and his shadow chancellor, Rachel Reeves, to raise the tax levels of the wealthy as part of a renewal programme ‚Äì and, I might add, to explain clearly to the public why this is essential. As she says, growth alone won‚Äôt solve ‚Äúbroken Britain‚Äù.  Ending non-dom status of the rich simply won‚Äôt solve the multiple issues a Labour government will need to address. Raising taxes from the top 5% certainly could. Time for some honesty and transparency. Jol Miskin Sheffield ‚Ä¢ Regarding Frances Ryan‚Äôs piece on taxation, according to the Office for National Statistics, the combined gross annual income of the top 1% of earners in the UK was ¬£605.5bn in 2020. Given the mess that Labour is likely to inherit, why not ask this top 1% to donate one year of their annual income to the Treasury ‚Äì given their wealth, this is¬†hardly likely to affect their standard of living, and the contribution to the public good would be their reward. Prof emeritus TD WilsonUniversity of Sheffield  ‚Ä¢ Have an opinion on anything you‚Äôve read in the Guardian today? Please email us your letter and it will be considered for publication in our letters section.

title: Mega-poll predicts disaster for Tories ‚Äì but reality could be even worse
content: For Conservative MPs opening their Daily Telegraph on Monday morning it was a distinctly gloomy start to the week: a mega-poll suggesting they are heading for a crashing general election defeat. And this was arguably an optimistic take. For one thing, some pollsters believe the YouGov conclusion of a 120-seat Labour majority could be an underestimate. Additionally, the poll‚Äôs organisers seem intent on using its findings to push the party further to the right on immigration, a move that will dismay many centrist Tories, and seems unlikely to stop the rot. The notable aspects of the poll come in two main parts. The first is its findings: YouGov surveyed 14,000 people and extrapolated the results to constituencies using the multilevel regression and poststratification model, or MRP. This predicted that the Conservatives would retain only 169 seats, 196 fewer than their 2019 total, while Labour would take 385, the Liberal Democrats 48 and the SNP 25. This would be a disaster for the Conservatives, resulting in 11 current cabinet ministers losing their seats, among them Jeremy Hunt, Grant Shapps and Gillian Keegan. But it could ‚Äì and might ‚Äì be worse. Rob Ford, a professor of politics at Manchester University, noted that the YouGov modelling appeared to play down the effect of tactical voting in many seats where Conservative MPs were at risk of challenge. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt seem very credible to me that in a Tory-Lib Dem marginal, 10% of people would still support Green, and not care either way about the opportunity to get rid of a Conservative MP. It does suggest that things could be even worse for the Conservatives,‚Äù Ford said. Another point of interest is the political backdrop to a large and very expensive polling operation. It was, the Telegraph said, commissioned by the Conservative Britain Alliance, a previously unknown organisation described only as a ‚Äúgroup of Conservative donors‚Äù. YouGov, the Telegraph added, worked with the Tory peer David Frost, who contributed an opinion piece arguing that the only way back from the brink for the party was to go much harder on immigration, seeking to tempt former Tory voters who are backing the Nigel Farage-founded Reform UK. ‚ÄúThe big problem is immigration, legal as well as illegal. That‚Äôs why this week‚Äôs vote on Rwanda is so important,‚Äù Frost writes. The Telegraph runs its own analysis arguing that Reform votes would play a part in 96 losses for the Conservatives, making the difference between a catastrophic loss and a hung parliament. The combined message is clear: copy Reform, notably on small boats and on migration more generally. Others, however, disagree. ‚ÄúThe Telegraph analysis works on the basis that all these seats would come back if every single Reform vote went back to the Conservatives ‚Äì that‚Äôs a mighty big ‚Äòif‚Äô,‚Äù Ford said. Even YouGov felt obliged to add a note to their in-house report on the polling to stress that the Telegraph analysis of Reform votes was ‚Äúnot a reliable way of measuring their impact‚Äù. Ford added: ‚ÄúWhere I do agree with David Frost is that the government is in a lot of trouble. But it doesn‚Äôt seem rational to me to endlessly focus on an issue where, the polling says, the voters don‚Äôt trust you, and you risk alienating the One Nation MPs. ‚ÄúTory MPs on the right think of the centrists a bit like Labour MPs think of the Lib Dems ‚Äì they either pretend they don‚Äôt exist, or that if they do, they won‚Äôt do anything. And it‚Äôs true they are more squishy than the right of the party, but there are enough of them who are angry and can only be pushed so far.‚Äù Tim Bale, a professor of politics at Queen Mary University of London, said that while the YouGov polling appeared solid, ‚Äúthe spin put on it by Frost and friends is something else altogether‚Äù. He said: ‚ÄúExhibit A would be their central claim that if Reform weren‚Äôt in the picture, the Tories could prevent Labour from winning an overall majority ‚Äì a claim that depends entirely on the batty assumption that every single voter who would otherwise vote for Reform would vote Tory instead. ‚ÄúEssentially, this is a laughably transparent attempt to scare Tory MPs into allowing the party, on the equally batty basis that immigration and woke are more important to voters than the economy and the NHS, to be pushed and pulled even further to the right ‚Äì and the tragedy is that it might just work.‚Äù

title: UK will not accept Red Sea being permanently closed, says Shapps
content:
Grant Shapps has said the UK will not accept the Red Sea being permanently closed to commercial shipping, as he left open the possibility that western forces might attack Houthi rebels in Yemen once more.
The defence secretary said on Monday the US-led airstrikes launched against the Houthis last week were designed to be a one-off military action designed to stop their attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea.
But he added that the US, UK and their international partners were watching carefully to see what the rebels do next as they assess whether further attacks are needed.
Speaking at Lancaster House in central London, Shapps said: ‚ÄúWe will watch very carefully; we will look at the patterns of what‚Äôs happening; we will check the capability; we will in particular, be interested to see those links between Tehran and the Houthis to see whether when we‚Äôre monitoring, whether there are shipments; whether we detect intelligence and the rest of it.
He added: ‚ÄúAlthough this was a distinct piece of precisely targeted military action, we will not put up with a major waterway, major shipping lanes being closed on a permanent basis.‚Äù
Shapps was outlining his vision for the UK‚Äôs military forces after just over four months in the job, arguing Britain‚Äôs participation in last week‚Äôs strikes in Yemen was evidence of how unstable the world was now.

 Related: Who are the Houthis and how did the US and UK strikes on Yemen come about? 

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve come full circle, moving from a postwar to prewar world,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAn age of idealism is being replaced by a period of hard-headed realism.‚Äù
He added that in this more unstable world, the military would need more money. ‚ÄúOur great resource has always been men and women who work tirelessly to protect our nation,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut to defend our nation from increasing dangers of tomorrow they must have what they need to do the job.‚Äù
Several Conservative MPs who watched the speech interpreted his words as a traditional pre-budget call for money made by successive defence secretaries before him. ‚ÄúThe message was pretty clear,‚Äù said one. ‚ÄúHe wants more from the Treasury.‚Äù
Shapps said in December he wanted to see the UK‚Äôs defence budget rise by as much as 50% to 3% of economic output, from just above 2% today.
Shapps will address MPs later on Monday as he defends the government‚Äôs decision to take military action against the Houthis without consulting parliament first.
 





Shapps told the BBC that briefing parliament before the strikes would not have been practical. He said: ‚ÄúOne of the issues with having a sort of full debate about those things upfront is it would have provided perhaps too much information in detail to the Houthis.
‚ÄúSo we needed to act. In fact, we did that with quite a lot of consultation ‚Äì with parliament, with the speaker, the leader of the opposition, and others. And of course, there‚Äôll be time today to have that public discussion in parliament as well.‚Äù
While the Houthis have said their attacks on shipping are simply aimed at Israel following its war on Gaza in response to the 7 October massacres by Hamas, Shapps dismissed this idea.
‚ÄúI know the Houthis are saying that it‚Äôs somehow connected, but actually, 50 different nations have had their ships attacked, so it quite clearly isn‚Äôt actually connected,‚Äù he said.
In an apparent sign that the rebels intend to carry on attacking ships, the US military said on Sunday night that US fighter aircraft had shot down an anti-ship cruise missile fired from a Houthi-controlled area of Yemen at one of its warships in the Red Sea.
The missile was fired towards the USS Laboon, which was operating in the southern Red Sea, US Central Command said in a statement, in what appears to be the first such attempt to strike a US destroyer. No injuries or damage were reported.

title: French woman ‚Äòheartbroken‚Äô after losing job in UK after Brexit speaks out
content: A French woman has spoken about how she lost her job in Shropshire and was left ‚Äúheartbroken‚Äù about life in the UK because of a mix-up over the immigration process for EU citizens launched after Brexit.  Sophie, who is married to a British man, was in the UK for five years before Brexit but went back to France in 2020 for 18 months after a family tragedy. Under the Brexit withdrawal agreement, the rights of British citizens in Europe and EU citizens in the UK to live and work in their country of residence before Brexit are protected. When she eventually applied to the EU settlement scheme (EUSS) in early 2022, Sophie knew she had missed the June 2021 deadline but also knew from the government website that late applications were being considered if there were ‚Äúreasonable grounds‚Äù for missing the deadline. Her application in early 2022 was, however, refused on the grounds that she had ‚Äúnot evidenced clearly enough‚Äù that she ‚Äúhad continued to live with my husband when I was in France which was a little confusing‚Äù. On legal advice, she decided to launch a formal appeal through the asylum and immigration tribunal system, a route open to all EU citizens applying for the EUSS. She sensed something was awry when she did not receive a certificate of application, a document that confirms the right to work and live in the UK while applications are being considered for the EUSS. Nonetheless, through a ‚Äúshare code‚Äù, a digital identification number issued by the Home Office for applicants, she was able to evidence she had the right to work and got a job in a logistics firm near her home. ‚ÄúThere was never really any problem. I was just waiting patiently for an answer. Using the share code my employer did the right-to-work check and it came back positive very quickly. ‚ÄúIt was only valid for six months so they renewed it again in July and then just at the start of December 2023 they ran the right-to-work check again and it came back that I didn‚Äôt have the right to work.‚Äù With employers facing fines of ¬£20,000 for employing illegal workers, Sophie received shock news. ‚ÄúThey told me they had to let me go. They did say, ‚Äòthis is your job and it‚Äôs not going anywhere‚Äô, but in the meantime I was effectively dismissed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve not been able to earn any money since December and in the middle of a cost of living crisis it‚Äôs a little bit tough.  ‚ÄúI am heartbroken, to be honest. I‚Äôve been in love with the UK since I was a little girl and this is why I came here. This situation seems dangerous but also foolish because I‚Äôm willing to work, to make a contribution to society. I want to work. I want to be autonomous, I don‚Äôt want to be claiming benefits. But they are not letting me.‚Äù  After inquiries were made to the Home Office last week by the Guardian, it emerged that Sophie may have made an application through the wrong route in the EUSS. She should have applied for the EU settlement scheme in its own right, not the family permit, as this was designed for relatives joining EU citizens in the UK from abroad. This may also explain why she was not issued a certificate of application. She is seeking legal advice, applying for the EU settlement scheme and hoping her late application will be approved. ‚ÄúThrough the past two years at no point did I have a case worker, a point of contact, or any guidance on my rights. The whole system feels like it is set up for failure and to push people through the paid-for visa route,‚Äù she said. A spokesperson for the Home Office said: ‚ÄúMore than two years have passed since the main deadline for applying to the EU settlement scheme, which was widely publicised. In line with the citizens‚Äô rights agreements, we continue to accept and consider late applications from those with reasonable grounds for their delay in applying.‚Äù

title: ‚ÄòNot a practice run‚Äô: Labour braves the cold before Kingswood byelection
content: You might think the idea of pounding the streets and banging on doors during a cold January would not be too enticing, especially when the prize for the victor vanishes in a few months time. But Damien Egan, Labour‚Äôs candidate for the Kingswood byelection, was beaming as he marched up and down the streets of a modern housing estate at the heart of a constituency in South Gloucestershire up for grabs after the sudden resignation of its Conservative MP, Chris Skidmore. ‚ÄúIt definitely wasn‚Äôt something I was expecting but I‚Äôm really excited about it,‚Äù Egan said. ‚ÄúI grew up in Kingswood. I really know the area. Once you‚Äôre on the streets, you get the feeling you have the chance to give a voice to those people you grew up with.‚Äù Skidmore, a leading Tory voice on green issues, resigned in protest againt his party‚Äôs dash for oil and gas, setting up a difficult byelection for Rishi Sunak. Over the last half century, Kingswood, has swung between the Tories and Labour. Skidmore won the seat in 2010 and had built up an 11,000 majority by 2019. The constituency is being abolished at the next general election, when Kingswood voters will find themselves in one of four different constituencies. Egan, who until last week was the mayor of Lewisham in south-east London, had previously been selected as the candidate for one of these, Bristol North East, a key Labour target. But when Skidmore stepped down, Egan resigned from his Lewisham job and headed to South Gloucestershire to fight for Kingswood. He is staying with his sister and looking for somewhere to rent, so is getting firsthand experience of a key election issue here ‚Äì soaring house and rental prices. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of people with kids living at home in their 20s. Getting on the housing ladder is hard,‚Äù he said. Egan has been struck by how rundown some things have become here. ‚ÄúPeople also talk a lot about how hard it is to get a GP or NHS dentist. Someone said it‚Äôs like the Victorian era, with people pulling out their own teeth.‚Äù Out campaigning with Egan was Kerry McCarthy, Labour MP for Bristol East and the shadow climate change minister, who got on well with Skidmore. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs gone for genuine reasons and it‚Äôs quite nice to have someone who hasn‚Äôt gone because of sleaze,‚Äù she said of the former Tory minister. McCarthy said people in the area, which has traditionally provided workers for big manufacturers such as Rolls-Royce, BAE Systems and Airbus, were interested to talk about the transition to green jobs. ‚ÄúThey get that net zero is the way to do it,‚Äù she added. The Kingswood byelection is also an important test for Labour‚Äôs hopes to challenge the Tories and the Liberal Democrats in south-west England. Luke Pollard, the Labour MP for Plymouth, Sutton and Devonport, said: ‚ÄúThere are about 60 parliamentary seats in the south-west. We have six currently and our objective is to get to 17. That makes this region as important as any in the country. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs seats in Cornwall or Bristol, the best way is to get on the doorsteps and have those conversations. There‚Äôs a lot of people who have left the Tories but haven‚Äôt necessarily arrived at their new destination.‚Äù There are clearly people in Kingswood looking for something new. ‚ÄòWe definitely do need a change,‚Äù said Graham Bond, a delivery driver. A Scot, Bond said he would vote Scottish National party if he could. ‚ÄúBut obviously they‚Äôre not standing. It‚Äôs between Labour and the Greens here for me.‚Äù His wife, Ruth Bruce, a businessperson, said: ‚ÄúAll the Tories are interested in is what they get out of it, what directorships they are getting, what connections they are making.‚Äù Ken Comley, a retired tour operator, stopped Egan and asked him to sort out a local graveyard. ‚ÄúBut I won‚Äôt be voting for him,‚Äù Comley said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll always vote Conservative because Mrs Thatcher gave us the chance to buy shares.‚Äù Aimie Green, who works in a florists on Hanham High Street in the constituency, said the byelection campaign was not the talk of the town. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs that much interest,‚Äù she said. Mat Knight, who owns a cycling shop in the high street, said he thought Skidmore had jumped ship because his constituency was disappearing. ‚ÄúThe Labour candidate has been here already ‚Äì he talked well about the high street and green issues,‚Äù said Knight. The Green party came fourth in Kingswood in 2019 but since then has the largest group on Bristol city council. Its national co-leader Carla Denyer said Skidmore‚Äôs resignation was a damning verdict on the Tories but argued that Labour should be doing more to challenge the government‚Äôs oil and gas policies. ‚ÄúKingswood is on the edge of Bristol, a city that is turning Green. We see increasing support for greens in surrounding areas as well,‚Äù she added. Meanwhile, Egan rejects the notion that the Kingswood campaign is a warm-up for his Bristol North East push, saying: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a practice run. The voters here need an MP.‚Äù He accepted the Tories had a big majority. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why have to be out every day. We‚Äôll be in our thermals speaking to as many people as possible.‚Äù

title: Why is UK being hit by medicine supply shortages?
content: The latest drug to be in short supply in the UK is a treatment for epileptic seizures. A notification from the Department of Health and Social Care last Wednesday informed doctors and pharmacists that Tegretol ‚Äì or carbamazepine ‚Äì 200mg prolonged release tablets would not be available until mid-January. It was said to be of ‚Äúmedium impact‚Äù, as such supply shortages go. The use of low-risk therapeutic alternatives, unlicensed imports or alternative strengths or formulations were the ways to proceed. An inconvenience on this occasion but a week earlier practitioners had been informed that supply of glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists, used by those with type 2 diabetes, would be problematic throughout 2024, and that doctors should immediately stop prescribing it to those seeking to lose weight. This time there was also a national patient safety alert requiring ‚Äúaction to be taken by healthcare providers to reduce the risk of death or disability‚Äù. Days before that, there had been notification that a tablet used by cancer patients to treat high levels calcium of the blood would not be available until late March. There is also a shortage of a brand of tablets for the treatment of heart-related chest pain, heart failure and oesophageal spasms. Women experiencing menopause who use the Estring 7.5 micrograms estradiol vaginal ring need also to look elsewhere and there is a supply issue with a range of tablets used by people with angina.  Interactive  As of 18 December, the list of medicinal shortages in the UK included 96 products, according to the British Generic Manufacturers Association. Thats is down on the 111 such shortages at the end of October but there have been a further 10 supply notifications from DHSC since then. The total is close to double the 52 medicines for which there was an issue in January 2022. The trend over the last few years is clear. A 2023 pressures survey by Community Pharmacy England found that 92% of pharmacy teams were dealing with medicine supply issues daily, an increase from 67% the year before. They reported that 87% of pharmacy teams members believed patient health was being put at risk. It is not just a UK phenomenon. A recent European Association of Hospital Pharmacists survey reported that 95% of hospital pharmacists across Europe were experiencing shortages. An EU medicines shortage working party met last month to discuss a critical shortage of five key medicines, with impediments to supply said to include the impact of the war in Ukraine on supply chains, a European Medicines Agency recommendation to suspend use of about 400 medicines tested by an Indian laboratory, as well as attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the extra regulatory paperwork that arises in some chains of supply due to Brexit. All these affect the UK too. But industry insiders say there are problems peculiar to Britain. The plummeting value of the pound following the Brexit referendum has made it more expensive for the NHS to buy medicines. Then there is the voluntary scheme introduced by the government in 2019 in an attempt to ensure that NHS spending on branded medicines did not grow by more than 2% in a year. As of the end of 2023, there was a 26% levy on revenues of drug manufacturers earned beyond the cap. The companies claim it has made the UK an unattractive place to do business. It has, they say, acted as a drag on investment. From this year that cap will rise to allow a 4% annual rise in spending. The British Generic Manufacturers Association says the government is still penny pinching. Then there is a lack of joined up planning and communication. In 2015, guidance published by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) prompted a hike in hormone replacement therapy (HRT) prescriptions but manufacturers proved unable to meet demand. There were still HRT shortages last year. In November 2022, pharmacists in the UK began reporting difficulties in procuring the antibiotic amoxicillin. At the same time Rishi Sunak was saying there was ample supply. A week later, a medicine shortage notification was issued, followed by an export ban. It is perhaps little wonder then that four in five pharmacy owners say they have experienced aggression from patients due to medicine supply issues. Patience with the system is also running out fast.

title: ‚ÄòBackstabbing is part of politics‚Äô: John Bercow joins US version of The Traitors
content: When he was the House of Commons speaker, John Bercow developed a combative reputation ‚Äì and after his tenure he was found to be a ‚Äúserial bully‚Äù and a liar. But now as he makes his reality TV debut, the man with the famous cry of ‚Äúorder!‚Äù is seeking to use his political experience to unleash chaos. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a retired politician,‚Äù Bercow said in the season premiere of the US version of The Traitors. ‚ÄúBackstabbing, deception are all part and parcel of the political life.‚Äù Bercow joins the Love Island winner Ekin-Su C√ºlc√ºloƒülu, Tamra Judge of The Real Housewives of Orange County, Maksim Chmerkovskiy of Dancing with the Stars and Marcus Jordan ‚Äì son of the basketball legend Michael Jordan ‚Äì as one of 21 celebrities competing at a castle in the Scottish Highlands for a cash prize ‚Äì the same venue as the UK version, broadcast by BBC. Three of the contestants have been chosen by the host, Alan Cumming, to sow chaos and purposely sabotage the others. While Bercow was not selected as a traitor, several of his fellow contestants suspected he was after he experienced ‚Äúbreathing difficulties‚Äù during the premiere. He blamed the difficulties on asthma, but others doubted his answer. ‚ÄúWhen you took your mask off, you said: ‚ÄòI have asthma‚Äô but you just said: ‚ÄòI was asthmatic as a child,‚Äô‚Äù said Big Brother‚Äôs Janelle Pierzina. She questioned what exactly Bercow told another contestant about his breathing issues, to which he replied: ‚ÄúLook, is asthma a lifelong condition?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the question I‚Äôm asking you,‚Äù Pierzina said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre answering this just like a politician.‚Äù In this season, Big Brother‚Äôs Dan Gheesling, Phaedra Parks from The Real Housewives of Atlanta and Survivor‚Äôs Parvati Shallow are the traitors, but at the end of the first episode Peppermint of Ru Paul‚Äôs Drag Race was voted off. A number of the other contestants voted for Bercow, however. Bercow served as Commons speaker for 10 years, with clips of his snarky retorts and cries for ‚Äúorder, order‚Äù while arbitrating Brexit debates and PMQs gaining the politician a cult following in the US and across Europe. ‚ÄúNo one on the British island can call ‚Äòorder, order‚Äô more beautifully than John Bercow,‚Äù the Dutch newspaper De Volkskrant stated in its 2019 profile of the speaker. He quit his Commons role in 2019. An independent inquiry in 2022 found that Bercow was a ‚Äúserial bully‚Äù and a liar and that he should be banned from holding a parliamentary pass. The former speaker was accused of throwing a mobile phone and swearing at officials, with the inquiry upholding 21 out of 35 complaints filed against him by former staff. Before the final report was published, Bercow criticised the way the inquiry was conducted, saying: ‚ÄúTo call it a kangaroo court is unfair to kangaroos.‚Äù

title: Keir Starmer defends stance on military action and Saudi arms sales
content: Keir Starmer has rejected claims he has watered down promises to introduce a law giving MPs a vote before military intervention and to stop selling weapons to Saudi Arabia. During his party‚Äôs 2020 leadership race, the Labour leader promised to introduce a ‚Äúprevention of military intervention act‚Äù that would stop ‚Äúmore illegal wars‚Äù and ensure military action could only be taken if a lawful case was made, the Commons had given its consent and there was ‚Äúa viable objective‚Äù. Starmer has backed the RAF strikes in Yemen with the US, which were authorised by Rishi Sunak without giving parliamentarians a say, but he insisted on Sunday there was ‚Äúno inconsistency‚Äù between the two positions. The Labour leader said he stood by the principle that military action should be put to parliament. ‚ÄúThere is obviously a huge distinction between an operation, the like of which we have seen in the last few days, and military action, a sustained campaign, military action usually involving troops on the ground,‚Äù he said. Asked if his plan to give the Commons a say related only to sending in ground forces, he said: ‚ÄúYes, because what I said when I made that pledge was that what I want to do was to codify the convention.‚Äù Starmer hinted the requirement for MPs to have a say may not need to be put in law. ‚ÄúI want to codify that ‚Äì it could be by a law, it could be by some other means,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not ruling out law.‚Äù Rejecting suggestions his move could anger the party‚Äôs leftwing, Starmer added: ‚ÄúNo Labour activist has ever said to me ‚Äòif urgent action is needed we should stop that in order for parliament to be convened‚Äô.‚Äù Before becoming Labour leader in 2020, Starmer said the UK ‚Äúshould stop the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia‚Äù over concerns about their use in Yemen‚Äôs civil war. He told the BBC he was still committed to reviewing all arms sales, but he refused to be definitive when it came to the Saudis. ‚ÄúWe will review the situation and the review will give us the answers to those questions.‚Äù The Conservatives accused Starmer of not being able to say ‚Äúwhat he‚Äôd do differently‚Äù as he ‚Äújust snipes from the sidelines‚Äù. Rejecting wider claims that he frequently changes his mind and contradicts his values and ideas, Starmer said: ‚ÄúLabour party members are predominantly, overwhelmingly, behind what we‚Äôve done with and to the party, to change the party. Four years ago, we were picking ourselves up, bruised, from a terrible election result ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúWe have ruthlessly changed the Labour party, put ourselves in a position where it can credibly contend in the election this year, and the overwhelming majority of Labour party members and supporters are delighted.‚Äù Starmer also defended taking a private jet paid for by Qatar to visit the country‚Äôs leader, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, to discuss the hostage situation in Gaza, despite Labour criticising Sunak‚Äôs ‚Äúprivate jet habit‚Äù. The Labour leader argued on Sunday there was a clear ‚Äúdistinction‚Äù between flying around England when trains could be used and using such trips to hold key talks with foreign leaders. According to parliamentary records, Starmer used the Qatari-provided jet to travel between the Cop28 climate conference and Doha, where he met the Emir of Qatar with three members of staff. The trip would have cost Qatar more than ¬£25,000. ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs a distinction, most people will understand, between flying in the circumstances I‚Äôve just described and using private jets to jet around England when trains will get you there nearly as quickly,‚Äù he told the BBC‚Äôs Sunday With Laura Kuenssberg. ‚ÄúThe long and the short of it was in Dubai I was having a number of discussions with international leaders about climate change as you would expect, but of course I was having a nearly equal number about the conflict in the Middle East ‚Äì how do we have a sustainable path to that ceasefire?‚Äù Starmer was also questioned for accepting the free flight to Qatar when he said previously he would not watch England in the World Cup there because of concerns about the Gulf state‚Äôs human rights record.

title: Let‚Äôs have fair fares on the buses | Letter
content: When we moved to Sheffield in 1974, I was amazed to find that it cost only 7p to travel the three miles into the city centre by bus, and that the service was so frequent (The Guardian view on fare-free public transport: good for people as well as the planet, 7 January). When I commented on this to my colleague Jeff Chapman, a South Yorkshire councillor, he explained that the aim was to make it a free service for everyone. Margaret Thatcher‚Äôs government put paid to that, of course. Sheffield‚Äôs roads are now jammed with traffic at peak times, which, despite bus lanes, slows their progress. And, without concessions, fares are many times more expensive than in the early 1970s. But don‚Äôt underestimate the difficulty in getting people out of their cars and on to public transport. There was plenty of resistance 50 years ago from middle-class motorists in Sheffield, who objected to subsidising the buses through local tax income. It will be even harder now that cars are designed to cosset their occupants and isolate them from the outside world. On the other hand, today there is a greater recognition of the impact of motor traffic on climate, pollution and safety.  Also, travelling by public transport is generally more relaxing. It is, after all, a ‚Äúhands-free‚Äù form of motoring, that doesn‚Äôt require sophisticated technology. John KirkwoodSheffield  ‚Ä¢ Do you have a photograph you‚Äôd like to share with Guardian readers? If so, please click here to upload it. A selection will be published in our Readers‚Äô best photographs galleries and in the print edition on Saturdays.

title: Luciana Berger given key Labour role after quitting over antisemitism
content: Luciana Berger has been given a key role in Labour‚Äôs mental health strategy, five years after she left the party over its handling of antisemitism cases. The former MP for Liverpool Wavertree has been appointed to lead a cross-government strategy focused on lowering suicide rates by appointing thousands of mental health professionals to support people who self-harm. Keir Starmer announced Berger‚Äôs new role at the Jewish Labour Movement (JLM) conference, as he assured members he would ‚Äúnever let antisemitism sneak back into the Labour party undercover‚Äù. He told the conference: ‚ÄúI see no greater cause in my leadership than this. This is my role.‚Äù Berger said Labour had turned a significant corner under Starmer‚Äôs leadership and expressed her excitement about leading the initiative. ‚ÄúMillions of people are experiencing poor mental health, without the necessary support to recover,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe absence of a proper plan to address the causes of poor mental health requires urgent attention. ‚ÄúLabour‚Äôs commitment to deliver a cross-government long-term strategy to tackle mental ill-health is an important step towards gripping this issue, and I am really excited to be leading this work.‚Äù Berger served as a shadow health minister between 2013 and 2016. As a Labour MP, she spoke of suffering a torrent of antisemitic abuse online and in person, and relied on police protection at the party‚Äôs annual conference. One man who sent her antisemitic threats was jailed for two years in 2017. While eight months pregnant, Berger faced a no-confidence motion in her constituency over her criticism of Jeremy Corbyn. The motion was withdrawn after it emerged that a key opponent in the local party had called her a ‚Äúdisruptive Zionist‚Äù. She subsequently left Labour in 2019 to join the new political party Change UK amid dissatisfaction with Corbyn‚Äôs response to antisemitism in the party.  Berger stood for the Lib Dems in the 2019 general election but lost, and rejoined Labour in February 2023 after an apology from Starmer. Berger will present recommendations before the next election about how to achieve Labour‚Äôs plans to prevent mental ill-health. Describing how the party had ‚Äúchanged irrevocably‚Äù under his leadership, Starmer told the conference: ‚ÄúI know there are many members of this community who still need to see more from us, and the work goes on. ‚ÄúBut I am proud of the steps we have taken so far, proud of the journey that JLM has led the party on.‚Äù As part of Labour‚Äôs plans to improve child health, Starmer has vowed to introduce mental health support in every school, community mental health hubs aimed at under-25s and recruit 8,500 new mental-health professionals. The Labour leader has also pledged to provide specialist self-harm training to the 8,500 additional mental health staff he committed to recruiting if his party wins the general election this year. The overall policy would cost ¬£440m, the party has said, and would be paid for by scrapping a private equity loophole it believes would raise as much as ¬£600m. The government has insisted it is taking action to reduce ‚Äúthe number of tragic suicides‚Äù, with an extra ¬£2.3bn a year going into mental health services to help a further 2 million people, as well as ¬£150m invested in crisis services. ‚Ä¢ In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on freephone 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 988, chat on 988lifeline.org, or text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis counselor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org

title: Allan Rogers obituary
content: Allan Rogers, the former Labour MP for Rhondda who has died aged 91, had, through the circumstances of his childhood, a passionate understanding of the difficult lives of many of his constituents in the valleys of south Wales. The youngest of 12 children of a disabled former miner who was unable to find work for over a decade after he was injured in a colliery accident, Rogers sought ways to improve the prospects for those he represented throughout his life ‚Äì first as a councillor in local government, then as a member of the European parliament for five years and subsequently, from 1983 until 2001, in the House of Commons. There, Rogers made an impact as a lively, enterprising and assertive MP. He was genial and popular on the Labour benches, but he was too much of a straight-talking class warrior for many in other parties. He pursued those responsible for financial mismanagement and fraud, and once complained bitterly to the public accounts committee (PAC): ‚ÄúSteal ¬£20 from the DHSS and you land up in jail; steal ¬£20m in the City and you land up in the Cayman Islands.‚Äù He was a doughty fighter for his constituency but was opposed to devolution to Wales, arguing instead for more direct government investment ‚Äì particularly in the valleys as the coal industry was closed. He condemned the Conservative government‚Äôs ‚ÄúValleys Initiative‚Äù for regeneration in 1989 as amounting to little more than ‚Äúa few brass lamps outside Rhondda‚Äôs pubs‚Äù. As well as the PAC (1986-88), Rogers was a member of the European scrutiny committee (2000) and the Welsh affairs committee (1986-87). Neil Kinnock, as Labour leader, appointed him a junior defence spokesman in 1987 and in 1992, under the leadership of John Smith, he joined the foreign affairs team. That year, he stood unsuccessfully against Doug Hoyle for the chairmanship of the parliamentary Labour party. In 1994 Tony Blair dropped him from the frontbench and he was made a member of the influential intelligence and security committee. Three years prior, Rogers had notably blown the whistle on British companies exporting arms to Iraq, when he called for an inquiry into the issue, claiming it contravened the UN resolution on the subject. This would lead to the damning Scott report. He was never in sympathy with Blair‚Äôs New Labour project, although he voted for Blair and John Prescott as leader and deputy. He announced in 1998, a year after Labour‚Äôs triumphant election win, that he would retire at the next general election, citing his disenchantment with government policy on education, health and welfare reform. ‚ÄúWorking-class people feel that the government has forgotten them in its desire to become the friend of big business, the City and media moguls,‚Äù he told the Daily Mirror. Born in Gelligaer in the Rhymney Valley, the son of Madeleine (nee Smith) and John Rogers ‚Äì who had been injured in 1926 and did not work again until the second world war brought other employment to south Wales ‚Äì Allan had become a member of the Labour party at 16. He was a clever boy and won a scholarship from his secondary school in Bargoed to Selwyn College, Cambridge, but was unable to take it up because administrative errors had led to the loss of his application to defer his national service. Instead he spent two years with the Royal Welch Fusiliers and in 1953 studied for a degree in geology at University College, Swansea. He worked as a geologist in the UK, Canada, the United States and Australia from 1956 until 1963, when he took up teaching. He recognised the crucial importance of education as a route to self-improvement and spent the next 15 years working as a schoolteacher and in adult education. As a tutor with the Workers‚Äô Educational Association for five years, he was a colleague of Kinnock, then in 1970 he became the WEA district secretary for mid and south Wales. He was elected to Gelligaer district council, where he served between 1965 and 1971, and in 1970 to Glamorgan (later Mid Glamorgan) county council. Although an anti-marketeer ‚Äì in common with many on the Labour left at the time ‚Äì Rogers stood in the first round of direct elections to the European parliament in 1979 and became the MEP for South East Wales. He won a reputation as an effective member, securing substantial European funding for his constituency but sought unsuccessfully to establish a register of MEPs‚Äô financial interests. He was a vice-president of the parliament, from 1979 until 1982, but membership did not change his views on European politics and he continued to advocate British withdrawal. He was already looking to further his career at Westminster. He failed to secure selection as the Labour candidate for Caerphilly in 1982, but the following year was chosen for Rhondda to succeed the shadow Welsh secretary, Alec Jones, whose death that March would have precipitated a byelection had the general election not been called for early June. A visiting professor at the University of South Wales from 1997, Rogers continued to work in education after leaving politics as chair of the Earth Science Education Forum from 2002 to 2010. He was a board member of the British Geological Survey from 2001 to 2005 and a fellow of the Geological Society, as well as a member of the Treorchy Workingmen‚Äôs Club and president of Penallta rugby football club. He loved all sport and had been a boxer in his youth. A jazz enthusiast and a keen gardener, he was at different times a dog breeder and owned a chip shop, managed by a family member. In 1955, he married his sweetheart from schooldays, Ceridwen James. She died in 2022. He is survived by their children, Cerilan, Richard, Alison and Catherine.  ‚Ä¢ Allan Ralph Rogers, politician, born 24 October 1932; died 28 November 2023

title: London Sphere debacle begs question ‚Äì has planning in the UK lost its way?
content: ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt keep banging our heads against the wall,‚Äù said James Dolan, the billionaire owner of New York‚Äôs Madison Square Garden arena, who last week abandoned a five-year effort to build a glowing orb concert venue taller than St Paul‚Äôs Cathedral in London. The Trump donor, who also owns the New York Knicks basketball team and built his first Sphere venue in Las Vegas, had foundered on the craggy rocks of the UK‚Äôs planning system ‚Äì the same one that took more than eight years to approve a fifth terminal for Heathrow airport and fails to build enough affordable housing but allows forests of speculative skyscrapers to stand partly empty. In barbed statements announcing it was taking its Sphere elsewhere (possibly Abu Dhabi), Dolan‚Äôs company said it would instead seek ‚Äúforward-thinking cities‚Äù and accused the authorities of treating its proposal as ‚Äúa political football‚Äù. The London mayor, Sadiq Khan, had started out welcoming the ‚Äúworld-class venue‚Äù only to turn against it as having ‚Äúan unacceptable negative impact on local residents‚Äù. The scheme was strongly opposed, not just by local residents, but also the rival AEG group, which runs a large concert venue inside the nearby O2 arena in Greenwich. But whatever the view of its merits, the episode adds weight to an increasingly urgent question: has planning in the UK lost its way? ‚ÄúThe British planning system is probably at the weakest it‚Äôs been since it‚Äôs creation,‚Äù Peter Rees, who for 29 years was the chief planner for the corporation of London, said. ‚ÄúIt has been emasculated by various politicians from Gordon Brown onwards.‚Äù Rees is one of the most respected planners in Britain today. From 1985 to 2014 he oversaw the Square Mile‚Äôs transformation from staid ancient banking quarter into today‚Äôs gleaming global financial hub. He oversaw the erection of 21st-century landmark towers such as the Gherkin, the Cheesegrater and the Scalpel. Planning has become highly politicised, he said, with power shifting too far from expert officials to non-expert councillors and government ministers, with the result that ‚Äúit is very much a casino‚Äù. Rees contrasted it to the ‚Äúcan-do‚Äù attitude of professional planning that delivered new towns in the 1960s and 1970s, a timely reference as Labour is pledging to build new towns if it wins the coming general election. ‚ÄúSince then it‚Äôs become over-political,‚Äù said Rees, now professor of places and city planning at University College London. ‚ÄúThe consequence is that it is almost impossible to know in advance which way a planning application will go.‚Äù Successive governments have seen planning as a lever to deliver economic growth, and weakened rules in an effort to ‚Äúget the planning system out of the way‚Äù, he said. ‚ÄúIf you are going to have a planning system based on rules, a planning application should pass or fail,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhat we don‚Äôt want is debate in political forums.‚Äù When Dolan proposed the Sphere, the culture secretary at the time, Matt Hancock, was effusive in his support, saying it ‚Äúcements both the capital and UK‚Äôs reputation for leading the world in music and the creative industries‚Äù. But with Hancock gone and Khan changing his mind after closer scrutiny, the scheme was dead. So developers who used to focus on building relationships with professional planners to get their schemes approved increasingly target non-expert elected politicians who are the ultimate arbiters, industry sources say. ‚ÄúIf you go to New York there‚Äôs a clear set of rules so everyone knows where they are,‚Äù said Peter Stewart, a former government design adviser and now a consultant to developers seeking planning approvals. ‚Äú[In the UK] planning policy guidance, national, local and in London says things that when unpicked and scrutinised turn out to be air. Everything is negotiable. When foreign investors come forward and say can we do something or can‚Äôt we, you have to say: ‚ÄòIt depends‚Äô.‚Äù In other words, it is a gamble. There has been a change in architectural fashions too, which Dolan perhaps did not grasp. ‚ÄúIn big commercial development there‚Äôs less appetite for jazziness and there‚Äôs a trend for sobriety,‚Äù Stewart said. The winners of the annual Stirling prize for Britain‚Äôs best building are more often calm studies in brick and block than the shiny architectural gymnastics of earlier years when clients and planners were hungry for ‚Äúiconic‚Äù architecture. And the climate emergency has become a big issue in planning departments, which are increasingly concerned about the carbon embodied in new proposals ‚Äì hence Marks & Spencer was last year refused permission to rebuild from scratch its store on Oxford Street. City leaders outside the capital have strived to create greater certainty for investors. In Manchester, for example, a wave of development that started with the reconstruction after the 1996 IRA bombing continues. This year Co-op Live, the UK‚Äôs largest indoor arena with 23,500 seats, will open next to Manchester City‚Äôs football stadium and a 76-storey residential tower was recently proposed ‚Äì the tallest yet in the city. But in Bristol, plans for a new arena, first mooted two decades ago, have not reached fruition, and last year one in five architects told a survey by the Royal Institute of British Architects that projects had recently been abandoned because of planning delays up from 7% in 2021. London‚Äôs planning policy straddles the approach taken in New York where massive dramatic buildings are allowed, albeit to strict codes, and cities such as Paris and Berlin where planning is highly conservative to maintain the historic urban cores, said Stewart. The development of the City of London is a case in point. In the past 20 years, ever taller and bulkier skyscrapers have risen up in the east of the financial district and 11 more are planned by 2030. The tallest of these, 1 Undershaft designed by Eric Parry, will rise to 75 storeys ‚Äì almost as high as the Shard, the UK‚Äôs tallest building. But in the area closer to Sir Christopher Wren‚Äôs 17th-century St Paul‚Äôs Cathedral, buildings must not disrupt historic views and have to stay low. In planning, as in so much else, Britain wants it both ways. Meanwhile, the casino element of the planning system encourages developers to gamble. It means ‚Äúwe are faced with these crazy applications ‚Äì the Tulip, the Sphere ‚Äì these things are turning London into a fairground,‚Äù said Rees. The Tulip, a bud-shaped viewing tower more than twice the height of the London Eye proposed by the company of a Brazilian billionaire, was rejected in 2021 by the current secretary of state with responsibility for planning, Michael Gove, because it was a waste of resources and he questioned ‚Äúthe quality of design‚Äù. One resident complainant said it ‚Äúreeks of desperation in its straining after ostentatious effect‚Äù. Another said it ‚Äúwould fit better into Dubai than London‚Äù. But while that was rejected, a few miles away the development of thousands of mostly expensive apartments around Battersea power station have been described as ‚ÄúDubai-on-Thames‚Äù. There is a lack of consistency. In British planning, as Stewart puts it, ‚Äúeverything is up for grabs‚Äù.

title: ‚ÄòLights are flashing red‚Äô over global instability, says David Cameron
content:
The ‚Äúlights are absolutely flashing red‚Äù on the global dashboard, the UK foreign secretary has said, insisting airstrikes against Houthi sites in Yemen were necessary to prevent future attacks by the group.
David Cameron said it was ‚Äúhard to think of a time when there has been so much danger and insecurity and instability in the world‚Äù.
Praising the prime minister‚Äôs judgment on the military action, he said Rishi Sunak had ‚Äúfollowed all the correct procedures‚Äù before the strikes, including assembling ministers, listening to advice, and consulting allies.
Asked on Sky News whether ministers had considered that the strikes could raise the likelihood of terrorist action in the UK, Cameron said: ‚ÄúThe threat level is set after careful consideration by the joint terrorist assessment centre and that is the right way of doing it; it is not in the power of politicians just to suddenly wake up one morning and change the threat level.
‚ÄúOur view is, look, take a step back from this, it is hard to think of a time when there has been so much danger and insecurity and instability in the world.
‚ÄúThe lights are absolutely flashing red, as it were, on the global dashboard and what we need at that time is strong leadership and a clear plan. That is what we have with the prime minister and the team in place.

 Related: Red Sea crisis could shatter hopes of global economic recovery 

‚ÄúAnd taking action, if you don‚Äôt act against the Houthis in the Red Sea, you are going to see more attacks, they are effectively terroristic attacks, you will see more of that.‚Äù
On Monday, Sunak will make a statement to parliament addressing the strikes. The foreign secretary said it would not have been right to have held a debate and vote before the UK-US military strikes because of ‚Äúoperational security‚Äù.
Cameron was speaking on the 100th day since Hamas attacked Israel, sparking the country‚Äôs bombing of Gaza. He denied that the Red Sea conflict was linked to the Israel-Gaza war.
When asked about the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, criticising the ‚Äúdisproportionate‚Äù UK-US strikes in Yemen, Cameron said: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt agree with what President Erdoƒüan has said. If you look at the action we have taken, it is actually backed by a very wide coalition of countries.‚Äù
He added: ‚ÄúHe is an important Nato ally, but in this case we don‚Äôt agree. We see this as completely separate from the Israel-Gaza conflict.‚Äù
Rejecting suggestions that the strikes had escalated the situation in the Red Sea, the foreign secretary told the BBC‚Äôs Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg: ‚ÄúThe escalation has been caused by the Houthis. I mean the point is, since 19 November you have had these 26 attacks.
‚ÄúThere have been more of them; they have been getting worse and, you know, not acting is also a policy; it is a policy that doesn‚Äôt work.‚Äù
While facing questions from a committee of MPs on Tuesday last week, Cameron suggested he was ‚Äúworried‚Äù that Israel might have broken international law with its bombing of Gaza. Asked on Sunday about his comments, Cameron said: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt say that.‚Äù
Asked whether he thought Israel had a case to answer in the international court of justice, where South Africa is accusing it of genocide, Cameron said: ‚ÄúNo, I absolutely don‚Äôt. I think the South African action is wrong; I think it is unhelpful; I think it shouldn‚Äôt be happening.‚Äù

 Related: How Houthi anger with Israel is reshaping the Middle East conflict  

The former head of MI6 Sir Richard Dearlove said the UK was ‚Äúabsolutely‚Äù right to launch strikes on the Houthis, but acknowledged there was a risk the action on the Houthis could inspire ‚Äúlone wolf‚Äù terror attacks in the UK.
Asked whether people in the UK should be feeling safer, Dearlove told Sky News‚Äôs Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre talking about the sympathetic radicalism and the events in the Middle East now motivating, let‚Äôs say, domestic terrorism, well, there‚Äôs a risk there.
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre looking at the Houthis specifically, do they have an infrastructure in the UK which could be a sort of conspiratorial organisation to mount a terrorist attack? Unlikely. Very unlikely in my view.‚Äù
Speaking to the BBC, the Labour leader, Keir Starmer, said there was ‚Äúno inconsistency‚Äù between his support for strikes on the Houthis, and his previous calls for parliamentary oversight of military action.
Starmer had said he would ensure military intervention was subject to approval by parliament, and considered passing an act of law to bind the government to this. Asked whether he had changed his position, he said: ‚ÄúNo, there is no inconsistency here.
‚ÄúThere is obviously a huge distinction between an operation, the like of which we have seen in the last few days, and military action, a sustained campaign, military action usually involving troops on the ground.‚Äù

title: Satnavs and Google Maps to be updated in readiness for driverless cars
content: Satnavs and Google Maps will soon include live data on road closures, parking restrictions and temporary speed limits in England under a UK government scheme aimed to ease drivers‚Äô pain and pave the way for driverless cars. Councils will be ordered to digitise all traffic regulation orders (TROs), short-term traffic measures such as temporary speed limits or road closures. Many TROs are kept on paper and not updated automatically on digital systems, meaning they are sometimes missing from satnav systems. On Monday, the roads minister, Guy Opperman, will announce that the data will be uploaded to a central database and made freely available online for satnavs and mapping services. It will also include the location of parking spaces. A spokesperson for the Department for Transport said digitising TROs would ‚Äúalso be crucial for ensuring autonomous vehicles can rely on accurate and up-to-date information so that they can operate safely once they start driving on British roads‚Äù. The move is part of the government‚Äôs plan for drivers, which purports to use ¬£8.3bn of funding originally earmarked for HS2. Last year, Rishi Sunak cancelled the northern leg of the high-speed rail line from Birmingham to Manchester. Sunak‚Äôs administration has sought to present itself as being ‚Äúon the side of motorists‚Äù ‚Äì a marked contrast from Boris Johnson‚Äôs government, which was enthusiastically pro walking and cycling. Ministers decided to prioritise driving over active travel because of worries among ministers about ‚Äú15-minute cities‚Äù, documents seen by the Guardian show. Opperman said: ‚ÄúThis government is on the side of drivers, which is why we‚Äôre making travelling by road much easier. Everyone knows the frustrations of being sent down a closed road by your satnav, so by going digital with our traffic information we‚Äôre making sure that drivers have the very latest travel information to rely on.‚Äù There are 50 million people with a driving licence in Britain, driving about 40m licensed vehicle. Cars are the most popular mode of personal travel, comprising 58% of trips in 2022 and 78% of distance travelled. The DfT said the database should be up and running by 2025.

title: I talked to Keir Starmer for three months: this is what I learned
content: Three months ago, our cameras captured Keir Starmer standing backstage at the ACC conference centre in Liverpool. The Labour leader, dressed in a smart dark suit and holding a cup of water, paced back and forth, a slight nervousness etched into his face. He was waiting to deliver perhaps the most important speech of his political career. For Labour advisers, this was his big chance to answer a key question that they believed would dominate all the way up to the 2024 general election: ‚ÄúIf not them [the Conservatives], why us [Labour]?‚Äù You may remember what happened next. Within minutes, Starmer‚Äôs speech was interrupted by a protester who somehow stormed on to the stage, threw glitter across his back and grabbed hold of his arm. If it wasn‚Äôt for the flick of genuine fear on Starmer‚Äôs face, a cynical journalist might have wondered had this moment been stage-managed? I joked to that effect in the moments after the speech when I caught up with the Labour leader, leaving with his wife to walk back to their hotel room. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he exclaimed, wagging his finger in my direction. But he was laughing, as he admitted this was the image he wanted to portray. ‚ÄúIf ever there was a symbol that the Labour party has changed from protest to power,‚Äù he said. When ITV‚Äôs Tonight programme was given exclusive up-close access to the Labour leader, this was one of many clues I got as to what drives Starmer politically. Over three months, I followed him from the highs of his party conference to the lows of division and resignations over Israel and Gaza. To understand his political journey, I went back to his old university in Leeds, asked about tax and immigration in a target constituency, pressed him on climate policies at the UN conference in Dubai, listened to his fears for his family ‚Äì and, of course, chatted about his football obsession on the way to his beloved Arsenal.   Related: Keir Starmer won‚Äôt just be battling the Tories this year but also the absence of hope | Andrew Rawnsley   So, politically speaking, who is the man tipped to be our next prime minister? Is he the idealistic lefty who wrote about the ‚Äúauthoritarian onslaught of Thatcherism‚Äù as a student in the 1980s? Is he the 2020 Labour party leadership hopeful who made 10 pledges, including mass nationalisations? Or is he the centrist who (after that moment of fear) almost revelled in the imagery of a protester being booted off stage at the final party conference before a general election year? Perhaps the best understanding came during a conversation in King‚Äôs Academy Prospect, a secondary school in Reading. We spoke in a design and technology lab in a wing of impressive buildings funded in the New Labour years. It was a late visit squeezed into Starmer‚Äôs brutal schedule. There, he blamed a dire economic backdrop for his decision not to lift the two-child cap on benefits. Pointing out that the previous Labour government invested heavily in public services, I asked him if he was sad that he couldn‚Äôt be as bold as Tony Blair. ‚ÄúWell, of course, but we‚Äôre inheriting a terrible situation,‚Äù he replied. And Starmer has clearly been advised that he shouldn‚Äôt offer the Tories even an inch on unfunded public spending. His mantra is that economic growth will turn the situation around, and he claims that his shadow cabinet is drumming up business investment now, to land on day one if it is elected.   My student self would also know the most important thing is to have a Labour government, otherwise it‚Äôs shouting into the void   For many, growth is a longer-term solution, so what about other more immediate choices, such as taxing people‚Äôs wealth? I turned back to Blair, reading this quote: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a burning ambition for me to make sure that David Beckham earns less money.‚Äù Did he disagree with that? ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Starmer responded without hesitation about Beckham or a similarly rich footballer today. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt disagree with that.‚Äù But if you are prime minister, I went on, would you want to take more money from the super-rich (non-doms aside) and redistribute it to the poorest? Again, a ‚Äúno‚Äù, without hesitation. ‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt how I want to grow the economy.‚Äù Starmer argued that while, of course, Labour believes in redistribution: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think redistribution is the sort of one-word answer for millions of people across the country‚Äù. He spoke of the dignity and respect of skilled work. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm afraid if it‚Äôs just redistribution, I think that fundamentally disrespects people.‚Äù If I was to judge the Starmer I was listening to against two of the other contributors to our programme ‚Äì Peter Mandelson, an architect of the 1997 Labour victory, and union leader Mick Lynch ‚Äì it was clear which way he was leaning. This Labour leader was far more Mandy than Mick (though his advisers would argue he is neither). Lord Mandelson, a key figure in Blair‚Äôs 1997 victory, praised Starmer for bringing the party back from ‚Äúa near-death experience‚Äù under Jeremy Corbyn. Meanwhile, Lynch told us: ‚ÄúThe Labour party has got to be a socialist organisation. We have got to take money off the rich and redistribute it to the rest of the communities in Britain. He‚Äôs got to identify with what working people need, not ‚Ä¶ with what the Daily Mail, the Telegraph and the Express are telling him to believe.‚Äù I wondered what had driven Starmer in the 80s. Back then, he was involved in producing a radical Trotskyist magazine called Socialist Alternatives. In one article, he argued that collective bargaining was not leftwing enough, handing too much power to the employers. And he did not hold back on the harm caused by Margaret Thatcher in the 80s. So why did he praise the former Conservative prime minister in a recent Sunday Telegraph article? Starmer asked if anyone would agree with exactly what they had believed at the age of 22. But, actually, he said he did agree that she delivered an ‚Äúauthoritarian onslaught‚Äù. ‚ÄúI would say the same now. What she had was a clarity of mission and a purpose ‚Äì but actually what she did was very destructive.‚Äù Was he a lefty then? Is he now? Starmer hesitated briefly, aware of the growing gravity attached to his comments as the election draws near. But still ‚Äúyes and yes‚Äù, he said. Still, something big has clearly shifted. I asked if defeat in the Hartlepool byelection in 2021 ‚Äì a sobering moment, by all accounts ‚Äì had led him to compromise those lefty principles to make way for a relentless pursuit of power? ‚ÄúWhen the electorate reject you as badly as they did in 2019, you don‚Äôt look at the electorate and say: ‚ÄòWhat are you thinking?‚Äô You look at yourself and change the party.‚Äù And this was the theme Starmer kept coming back to: the hopelessness of opposition.  He took every chance to stress how he had changed the party, moving Labour towards the centre ground (although some in the party would argue passionately that this is moving to where voters are, and they are in a different place in 2024 compared with 1997) and embracing the idea that he had been ‚Äúruthless‚Äù in doing so. He said it again as we walked up to the Arsenal and talked about how politics compares to football. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about winning. You know some people say: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs the taking part that counts‚Äô. I don‚Äôt.‚Äù Surely you don‚Äôt say that to your children, I suggested. But he doubled down: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt subscribe to any of that,‚Äù he said. But what might a young Starmer, who was clearly driven by a desire to tackle injustice and inequality, say to his older self, who won‚Äôt commit to lifting a two-child benefit cap or taxing the super-rich more than he has said so far? ‚ÄúThe Keir Starmer of my student days would also know that the most important thing is to have a Labour government, otherwise it‚Äôs shouting into the void.‚Äù But he did concede that an idealistic young Starmer would probably want him to go further ‚Äì especially if he wins.  ‚Ä¢ Tonight: Keir Starmer ‚Äì Up Close will air on ITV1 at 8.30pm on 18 January

title: Rishi Sunak says UK acted in ‚Äòself-defence‚Äô with Yemen airstrikes
content: The prime minister has said the UK acted in ‚Äúself-defence‚Äù with military strikes in Yemen intended to ‚Äúde-escalate tensions and restore stability to the region‚Äù, as he faced calls for greater parliamentary scrutiny. Speaking from Ukraine, Rishi Sunak said that in the face of this aggression ‚Äúwe will always stand up for the rule of law‚Äù after a series of attacks by Houthi rebels on shipping in the Red Sea. However, the Liberal Democrats, the Scottish National party and the former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn have urged the prime minister to recall parliament to seek approval for the military assault, while warning about the risk of escalation in the Middle East. Labour called for the legal advice in relation to the strikes to be published.   Related: The Guardian view on strikes on the Houthis: action to contain this crisis might fuel it | Editorial   Sunak said he would make a statement to MPs on Monday about ‚Äúlimited and necessary‚Äù military strikes in Yemen. Grant Shapps, the defence secretary, briefed MPs on a call on Friday but did not take any questions. A senior Conservative, David Davis, said it appeared to be ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù self-defence but that if the UK government intended to widen and intensify the military action in an aggressive way, then the prime minister ought to seek parliamentary approval with a vote of MPs. ‚ÄúIn the event that they want to do a Libya- or Syria-type thing, that has to be preceded by a proper debate and authorisation by the House of Commons. There is of course a risk of escalation. If they up the ante and you have to hit what they‚Äôre upping the ante with, that‚Äôs still defensive,‚Äù Davis said. ‚ÄúBut if, on the other hand, they want to take major action, let‚Äôs say to choke off Iranian supply lines, because we know that‚Äôs Iranian, that‚Äôs parliament first. This has changed in modern times ‚Ä¶ It is not that you don‚Äôt do it because of the threat of escalation. The test is whether it‚Äôs aggressive action.‚Äù The military action was backed across the Conservative party and by the Labour frontbench, with Keir Starmer saying his party was ‚Äúfully supportive‚Äù of the action. Asked how concerned he was that MPs would not have the opportunity to debate the strikes until Monday, Starmer told broadcasters on a visit in Bury in Greater Manchester: ‚ÄúI want the prime minister to make a statement as soon as possible, but the principle of taking action against the Houthi rebels is really important.‚Äù Malcolm Rifkind, a Conservative former foreign secretary, now chair of the Audere Group, said there had been a risk that without any defensive action the Houthis would have accelerated their attacks. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve chosen a whole pattern of behaviour which has been attacking, as it were, noncombatant ships ‚Äì they haven‚Äôt been attacking Israeli targets. They‚Äôve been attacking normal commercial shipping, going about its normal business. And they‚Äôve done so with significant damage,‚Äù Rifkind said. ‚ÄúIf action was not being taken there is no reason why the Houthis would not have continued doing this, and indeed accelerated and increased it in a significant way.‚Äù Alistair Burt, another Conservative former Foreign Office minister, said: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we have moved into a convention where every military action needs the prior approval of parliament. I think we have got a convention where, if you‚Äôre going to commit significant numbers of ground troops, then that is likely to need parliamentary sanction. But it has always been the case that the government has been able to take executive action to deal with an imminent threat and then be accountable to parliament afterwards, and I think that‚Äôs entirely proper.‚Äù Lindsay Hoyle, the Commons speaker, had said MPs should be updated ‚Äúat the earliest possible opportunity‚Äù and that he would recall parliament at the weekend if needed, but the prime minister said this was not required.   Related: Who are the Houthis and how did the US and UK strikes on Yemen come about?   In a TV clip recorded in Kyiv before talks with the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Sunak said inaction over the attacks on ships by Houthi rebels, including a barrage seemingly aimed at western warships, risked destabilising the global economy. ‚ÄúOver the last month, we‚Äôve seen a significant increase in the number of Houthi attacks on commercial shipping in the Red Sea that‚Äôs putting innocent lives at risk,‚Äù Sunak said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs disrupting the global economy, and it‚Äôs also destabilising the region. And in that time we‚Äôve also seen the single biggest attack on a British navy warship that we‚Äôve seen in decades.‚Äù Sunak described the US-led strike as ‚Äúlimited and necessary action in response to a specific threat in self-defence‚Äù, which was intended to ‚Äúdegrade and disrupt Houthi capability‚Äù. Asked what would happen if the strikes did not curb Houthi attacks on shipping, Sunak replied: ‚ÄúInitial indications are that those strikes have been successful. We‚Äôll continue to monitor the situation. But it‚Äôs clear that this type of behaviour can‚Äôt be met without a response.‚Äù The Commons ended its business for the week on Thursday and is not due to reconvene before Monday afternoon. MPs can be recalled to sit over weekends if there is an urgent matter to consider. So far the Lib Dems and the SNP have called for MPs to sit over the weekend. Speaking in Kyiv, Sunak said an early recall was not needed. ‚ÄúIf you look at similar situations in 2015 and 2018, a statement was made to parliament after the action and that‚Äôs what I will be doing on Monday ‚Äì I‚Äôll be making a full statement in parliament and taking questions.‚Äù Layla Moran, the Lib Dems‚Äô foreign affairs spokesperson, said there was a need for MPs to have a say. ‚ÄúParliament should not be bypassed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúRishi Sunak must announce a retrospective vote in the House of Commons on these strikes and recall parliament this weekend. ‚ÄúWe remain very concerned about the Houthis‚Äô attacks. But that makes it all the more important to ensure that MPs are not silenced on the important issue of military action.‚Äù The strikes on Thursday night were the first to be launched against Houthi forces since they started targeting shipping in the Red Sea, a key international trade route. The Ministry of Defence said four Royal Air Force jets struck two Houthi facilities that were involved in the targeting of HMS Diamond and US navy vessels on Tuesday. One was a site in Bani, in the country‚Äôs north-west, and the other was the Abs airfield, near the west coast. The US air force said it struck more than 60 targets at 16 sites in Yemen. The UK and US had non-operational support from Australia, Bahrain, Canada and the Netherlands.

title: Sunak seeks stature on the global stage ‚Äì and to keep trouble away from home
content: Returning from an overseas trip last year that had been broadly seen as a success, Rishi Sunak was heard privately observing that a truism of foreign policy is that even when you get things right, voters tend to not especially notice or care. Time will tell whether Sunak‚Äôs decision to throw in the UK‚Äôs lot with US-led attacks on Houthi forces will stem a spate of attacks on international shipping. But for now, the strike has won support from the bulk of British MPs, despite a few qualms about a lack of prior parliamentary consultation.   Related: Rishi Sunak pledges ¬£2.5bn in military aid to Ukraine during Kyiv visit   Almost immediately after chairing the cabinet call which rubber-stamped the mission on Thursday evening, Sunak departed on an even less controversial foreign policy mission, heading to Kyiv to promise more UK military aid for Ukraine. Does all this have much meaning for the trajectory of UK politics in an election year? In one sense not especially, not least because it seems fairly clear that had Keir Starmer been the occupant of No 10, policy towards the Houthis and Ukraine would be almost identical. But when you are a prime minister staring balefully at a 20-point deficit in the polls, even the traditionally more bipartisan arena of foreign policy will inevitably be viewed through the prism of political manoeuvrings. And this is where the incumbent PM has an advantage. One of the other cliches of overseas policy is that even if surveys routinely show it ranks low on the lists of issues voters cite as a priority, it rarely does a prime minister harm to be photographed alongside other leaders, especially charismatic and popular ones like Volodymyr Zelenskiy, the Ukrainian president. Boris Johnson was a famously keen supporter of the Ukrainian cause and a habitual visitor to Kyiv, and Sunak will have enjoyed the optics of Zelenskiy awarding him Ukraine‚Äôs Order of Liberty, however sheepish he looked as he was handed the medal inside a vast presentation case. ‚ÄúThere is definitely something in the claim that standing next to famous international figures reinforces the sense of a person‚Äôs seriousness, particularly if they are someone lacking in seriousness,‚Äù said Anand Menon, director of the UK in a Changing Europe thinktank and professor of European politics and foreign affairs at King‚Äôs College London. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also one of the very few of areas where Sunak has a united party. There are vanishingly few issues now where all his MPs will say ‚ÄòWell done‚Äô, and this is one of them.‚Äù The political downside for the prime minister is that when it comes to Yemen and Ukraine, such unanimity extends to most Labour MPs, and particularly to Starmer. One potential avenue for highlighting difference with Labour is the fact that the Houthi rebels began their attacks on shipping in the Red Sea after Israel‚Äôs invasion of Gaza in response to the 7 October massacre by Hamas, an issue Starmer‚Äôs party has seen frontbench resignations regarding his refusal to call for an immediate ceasefire. Similarly, a controversial bill banning local councils from boycotting Israel, voted on by MPs this week, is viewed by many as an attempt to create a wedge with Labour, and has faced criticism from some Conservative MPs. Menon also notes that a genuine political imperative for Sunak is trying to quell the attacks on vessels in the Red Sea ‚Äì the impact on commercial shipping, with many container ships now being re-routed around South Africa‚Äôs Cape of Good Hope, has a knock-on effect on not just journey times but also cost. ‚ÄúAs well as being an administration that is pretty happy to stick closely to the Americans, this is an administration that is obsessed with the cost of living and the dangers of inflation returning,‚Äù Menon said. ‚ÄúVoters‚Äô awareness of foreign policy might be limited, but with Covid, and the war in Ukraine, and to an extent with Brexit, the idea that stuff that happens outside our borders has a material impact on us in our lives is, I think, now fairly standard. ‚ÄúCertainly, your average voter is probably more likely to know what a supply chain is now than would have been the case five years ago.‚Äù

title: Labour considers non-dom tax plan that would raise ¬£1bn less than initial pledge
content: Labour plans to scrap non-dom tax breaks would raise about a billion pounds less than the ¬£3.2bn previously claimed, under an option being considered to allow a four-year grace period for those with the status. Research suggesting that scrapping the breaks could raise ¬£3.2bn a year was cited by Labour when it announced the plans in 2022 to scrap rules allowing some wealthy people to avoid tax on foreign earnings if they have lived in the UK for less than 14 years. The shadow chancellor, Rachel Reeves, has said abolishing the tax break in full would raise that amount each year and that Labour would use the money to expand the NHS workforce. However, the party is also considering new regimes for temporary residents. One option under consideration is for individuals to be be able live as non-domiciles in the UK for four years before they pay the full UK tax, it is now understood.   Related: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?   ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve actually been fairly conservative, with a small c, in terms of how much we think it will raise,‚Äù Wes Streeting told LBC on Thursday in relation to the overall policy. ‚ÄúWe put the number [at] about ¬£2bn; ¬£1.6bn will go to the NHS, the rest will go to primary school breakfast clubs,‚Äù the shadow health secretary said.
